I am worried, this O-line is built to give Carr more then enough time to make a wide variety of passing plays. Richardson,Murray and Helu though veterans are guys who are still young and trying to either rehab or develop their game. They MAY become monsters but if you can't give them a whole to run through problems crop up quickly. I said it last year, MJD needed holes to run through since he was no longer able to be that versatile back anymore who could dance around the field as a scat back and then get hard nosed and pound the snot out of DEFENSIVE TACKLES!!! Not linebackers or Defensive Ends, who tend to be lighter,more nimble and not as physically menacing but the interior linemen who look like they walk into every Las Vegas buffet and smile as if to say "Challenge Accepted", then bench their own weight in the gym. Richardson and Murray can grow into players that can smear defenses on the inside but they need an O-line to open up holes, generate a rhythm with and get the ground attack going. This is key to allowing us to set the tone for games by managing the clock and creating confusion as to potential plays.

I agree with You Ryan, about the Raiders putting a Team on the field that's no joke and Crabtree probably doesn't have the wheels to get free but He does have the hands. As far as Musgrave being with Philly, that was years ago and He was an assistant. That was long before Chip Kelly opened up the passing game. I think it was about  15 years ago... He was Q.B. Coach last year (with Philly) and Foles, Sanchez, and Vick didn't have great years. With Jacksonville and Minnesota He called a conservative run first Offense. Like I said, Musgrave has only had one season where He called more passes than runs.

You're assuming a lot Ryan, anybody that watched the Vikings play knows Musgrave  calls a conservative, run first Offense. Secondly, I expect a lot more connections over the middle to the slot with Crabtree or Streater and either Rivera or Clive in there too. Don't forget Marcel Reese or Hedu on the outlet..
I'm not saying Cooper wont get His chances but You have to consider the right side of the O-Line, We're still weak on the pass protection there. That might make Carr have to check down a lot more than Anyone wants to see especially if Cooper breaks free after 20 yds.

Musgrave has been an OC for 2 teams in 6 years Junior. He's only had 1 season where He called more pass plays than rushes and He's called way less pass plays over the last 6 years than the AVERAGE Offensive Coordinator in the League.He's had 4 seasons where His Team was in the top half of the League in rushing attempts... When the Raiders announced Musgrave as OC every expert I heard said He calls a conservative, run first Offense. As far as not having a Q.B... He had Byron Leftwich in His first 2 years with Del Rio as HC (Jacksonville) an average passer with a big arm, in His last 4 years He had Ponder, Anybody that watched the Vikes play knows Ponder has a big, accurate arm, makes decent decisions under pressure, and at times, could carry the Offense with His abilities. The Vikes got to the playoffs in Ponders second year. So, maybe You should do Your homework before You start changing the things Musgrave is known for and imagining He's suddenly going to change into some hard charging, risk taking OC when the evidence shows Him to be a conservative, run first playcaller.

The next SB he was handing the Vince Lombardi Trophy to "Just Win Baby" Davis, on National T.V., in the Raiders lockeroom....and THAT is the reason two of the BEST, for that era, QB's are not in the HoF. Just read a great article about the state of the Oakland Raiders; overall, not just "We have a QB, and Mack" 

Because #Raidernation we are gonna need more than Derek Carr & Amari Cooper, to make a playoff run ... that's just "Keeping it 100" ... an honest look at the 3 players who are being hyped to the point of "unachievable" performance levels will tell you there are questions that need answered, at best. 
Every position you look at on the Raiders roster; from CB, to RB, is a big question mark; 

Let me put it this way - 

This could either be a "Cinderella" year; or a devastating "Heart breaker", that's the dynamic I see here at work ... and I'm not willing to put my stamp on anyone. 

That's another amazing part of this upcoming season for Oakland - "from Bucky brooks to Joe Quarterback at the sports bar" everyone has staked their credibility as an analyst on some really "if'y" players here ... it's weird 
They've all but anointed Carr, a first ballot Hall of Famer, and this kid from Bakersfield hasn't put together "ONE WINNING DRIVE" yet ???? 
And, While I'd agree that Mack is a dangerous human being, with an incredible work ethic - I stop there ?? 4 sacks in 16 starts is hardly a defensive nightmare for any DC ? 
And, Amari Cooper hasn't even took an NFL snap yet.. No disrespect to Coop; he can run fast through some cones, but can he beat Richard Sherman deep ? ..period 

These are all truths people 
Truths from a lifelong Raider fan with crazy trivia and stats in his head that most don't even know about immediate family haha 
I can tell you who played Left Tackle in 1974 without Google, so this ain't my first Rodeo guys. 

You can sum up the 2015 Oakland Raiders with one statement 
"They have a lot of good young players" 

I don't see anything more than that at this point - and I'm not ready to say Carr is anything but a prospect at QB with a ton of unanswered questions after starting his entire rookie year. 

One thing is certain here 
Art Shell may have played a "near perfect game" against Jim Marshall in Superbowl XI ; but nothing at this moment is "close to that kind of perfection" going into training camp people
